section.title: Installation Prerequisites
section.para: The Mindquarry Collaboration Server can be installed on any operating system, provided following prerequistes are met.

section.title: Installing Java 6
section.para: If you do not already have Java 5 or higher installed, download the JDK 6 from Sun. It is available for Windows, Linux and Solaris. Users of Mac OS X 10.4 Tiger have Java 5 already installed.

para.phrase: For many Linux distributions there are packages of Java 5 or Java 6 available from the Linux distributors.

section.title: Installing Apache 2
section.para: Apache 2 is the HTTP server that is used to provide the Subversion repositories for file sharing. Additionally it can be used to secure the Mindquarry installation by adding SSL encryption. Apache 2 is available for download from the Apache Software Foundation. There are binary packages for Windows, Linux, Mac OS X and many UNIX derivates.

tip.para: The easiest way of getting up and running with Apache on Windows is downloading the Mindquarry Prerequisites package from the Mindquarry Download site.

section.para: For many Linux distributions there are packages of Apache 2 available from the Linux distributors.
Another recommended way of installing Apache 2 is using the OpenPKG meta-packaging software that provides easy-to install packages for many Linux distributions and UNIX derivates.

note.para: Mac OS X comes with a pre-installed Apache 2. As this version is not compatible with most binary packages of Subversion, it is recommended to use a Fink or MacPorts package.

section.title: Installing Subversion
section.para: Subversion is the version control system that powers Mindquarry's file sharing. It is available for download from the Subversion Open Source project's Download site. There are packages available for Micosoft Windows Red Hat Linux, Fedora Core, Debian, FreeBSD, Solaris and Mac OS X.

note.para: The Subversion Server cannot be installed on Windows 95, Windows 98 or Windows ME. You need at least Windows 2000, Windows XP, Windows 2003 Server or Windows Vista.

tip.para: The easiest way of getting up and running with Subversion on Windows is downloading the Mindquarry Prerequisites package from the Mindquarry Download site.

section.para: Another recommended way of installing Subversion is using the OpenPKG meta-packaging software that provides easy-to install packages for many Linux distributions and UNIX derivates.

section.title: Installing mod_perl
section.para: mod_perl is a module for the Apache 2 web server that allows you to configure Apache to use Mindquarry's authentication to prevent unauthorized access to the shared files. mod_perl in turn requires Perl, which is preinstalled on nearly every Linux, Mac OS X and UNIX operating system and is available for Windows from ActiveState in a bundle called ActivePerl.
Following perl modules must be present in order to authenticate Apache 2 against Mindquarry:

listitem.para: LWP::UserAgent, which is part of every standard Perl installation

tip.para: The easiest way of getting up and running with mod_perl on Windows is installing ActivePerl and downloading the Mindquarry Prerequisites package from the Mindquarry Download site.

section.para: Another recommended way of installing Perl and mod_perl is using the OpenPKG meta-packaging software that provides easy-to install packages for many Linux distributions and UNIX derivates.

section.title: Installing Mindquarry
section.para: In order to install Mindquarry on Microsoft Windows, following steps are neccessary:

step.para: Download the Mindquarry Installer from the Mindquarry Download site
Double-click the Installer and follow the Instructions

section.para: Mindquarry is then available as a system service and can be started from the administration panel.
In order to install Mindquarry on an operating system without an installer, following steps are neccessary:

step.para: Download a Mindquarry binary package for yor operating system from the Mindquarry Download site
Unpack the binary package and copy it to a location of your choice. Mindquarry recommends /opt/mindquarry as the installation directory.

section.para: Mindquarry can then be started by running the /opt/mindquarry/bin/mindquarry script.
In the future there will be packages available for most Linux distributions that allow installation of Mindquarry using the operating system's package management.

section.title: Configuring Mindquarry
section.para: All configuration of Mindquarry is handled in /opt/mindquarry/etc/mindquarry-webapplication.properties. This file is a simple list of name-value-pairs. A line starting with a has (#) is ignored. Most properties are tuned for running Mindquarry out of the box, you only need to configure three settings:

listitem.para: How your Mindquarry server is called. Use this to distinguish one Mindquarry installation from another. This could for instance be the name of your company or your workgroup.
The location where Mindquarry's file sharing repositories are located. Usually you need to replace your.mindquarry.server with the actual DNS name of the machine where Mindquarry is installed.
The location where Mindquarry is installed and available from the network. Usually you need to replace your.mindquarry.server with the actual DNS name of the machine where Mindquarry is installed.
Where Mindquarry's data files are stored.
Where Mindquarry's file sharing repositories are stored.
Where Mindquarry's search index is stored.

section.title: Configuring Apache
section.para: Apache needs configuration for three purposes: Requests to the Mindquarry application should be handled by Mindquarry. Requests to the Mindquarry file sharing repository should be handled by Subversion and requests to the Mindquarry file sharing repository should be authenticated by Mindquarry.

example.title: Running Mindquarry in a virtual host
example.programlisting:
NameVirtualHost *:80 DavLockDB /var/lock/apache PerlRequire /opt/mindquarry/perl/Mindquarry/Authenticate.pm <VirtualHost *:80> ServerName your.mindquarry.server <Location /repos> DAV svn SVNParentPath /opt/mindquarry/data/docs SVNAutoversioning on
PerlAuthenHandler Mindquarry::Authenticate PerlSetVar AuthBase "http://localhost:8080/files/authorise" AuthType Basic AuthName "Mindquarry Document Repository" Require valid-user </Location> ProxyRequests Off RewriteEngine On RewriteCond %{REQUEST_URI} !^/(repos|error)/(.*)$ RewriteRule ^/(.*)$ http://localhost:8080/$1 [P,NC] ProxyPassReverse / http://localhost:8080/ </VirtualHost>
example.para: In this example only the ServerName directive needs to be changed, all other directives are perfect for a default installation. If you changed the Mindquarry installation path, you need to revise the PerlRequire directive. If you changed the mindquarry.repos.path configuration, you have to revise the SVNParentPath directive.

appendix.title: Troubleshooting & FAQ
appendix.para: Support for Mindquarry is also available from the Mindquarry Support site.

question.para: I get file not found errors when restarting Mindquarry under Linux. There are messages about too many open files.

answer.para: This is most likely due to security limits set by your Linux distribution. The problem can be solved by modifiying the /etc/security/limit.conf file by adding following lines:
answer.programlisting: mindquarry soft nofile 65536 mindquarry hard nofile 65536
answer.para: This example assumes, Mindquarry is run as user mindquarry.

question.para: After some time of inactivity, Mindquarry complains about some files in the /tmp directory cannot be found.

answer.para: Some operating systems as RedHat Enterprise use tools like tmpwatch for deleting files that are not use for a certain period of time. If this is the case then, deactivate this recurring task by deleting it from /etc/cron.daily/tmpwatch.
